doc.title: EMBOSS

description.text: European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite

doc.reference: EMBOSS: The European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite (2000) Rice,P. Longden,I. and Bleasby, A. Trends in Genetics 16, (6) pp276--277

description.text: Needleman-Wunsch global alignment of two sequences

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory
fieldset.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory
fieldset.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.label:
Matrix file?
Eblosum30 Eblosum35 Eblosum40 Eblosum45 Eblosum50 Eblosum55 Eblosum60 Eblosum62 Eblosum62-12 Eblosum65 Eblosum70 Eblosum75 Eblosum80 Eblosum85 Eblosum90 Eblosumn Ednafull Ednamat Ednasimple Epam10 Epam100 Epam110 Epam120 Epam130 Epam140 Epam150 Epam160 Epam170 Epam180 Epam190 Epam20 Epam200 Epam210 Epam220 Epam230 Epam240 Epam250 Epam260 Epam270 Epam280 Epam290 Epam30 Epam300 Epam310 Epam320 Epam330 Epam340 Epam350 Epam360 Epam370 Epam380 Epam390 Epam40 Epam400 Epam410 Epam420 Epam430 Epam440 Epam450 Epam460 Epam470 Epam480 Epam490 Epam50 Epam500 Epam60 Epam70 Epam80 Epam90 Sssub
This is the scoring matrix file used when comparing sequences. By default it is the file 'EBLOSUM62' (for proteins) or the file 'EDNAFULL' (for nucleic sequences). These files are found in the 'data' directory of the EMBOSS installation.

Gap opening penalty (Floating point number from 1.0 to 100.0)?
The gap open penalty is the score taken away when a gap is created. The best value depends on the choice of comparison matrix. The default value assumes you are using the EBLOSUM62 matrix for protein sequences, and the EDNAFULL matrix for nucleotide sequences.

Gap extension penalty (Floating point number from 0.0 to 10.0)?
The gap extension, penalty is added to the standard gap penalty for each base or residue in the gap. This is how long gaps are penalized. Usually you will expect a few long gaps rather than many short gaps, so the gap extension penalty should be lower than the gap penalty. An exception is where one or both sequences are single reads with possible sequencing errors in which case you would expect many single base gaps. You can get this result by setting the gap open penalty to zero (or very low) and using the gap extension penalty to control gap scoring.
Apply end gap penalties. Yes No

End gap opening penalty (Floating point number from 1.0 to 100.0)?
The end gap open penalty is the score taken away when an end gap is created. The best value depends on the choice of comparison matrix. The default value assumes you are using the EBLOSUM62 matrix for protein sequences, and the EDNAFULL matrix for nucleotide sequences.

End gap extension penalty (Floating point number from 0.0 to 10.0)?
The end gap extension, penalty is added to the end gap penalty for each base or residue in the end gap. This is how long end gaps are penalized.

Brief identity and similarity?
Yes No
Brief identity and similarity
Name of the output alignment file
Choose the alignment output format Fasta Msf Pair Markx0 Markx1 Markx2 Markx3 Markx10 Srs Srspair Score Unknown Multiple Simple Match

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This is the scoring matrix file used when comparing sequences. By default it is the file 'EBLOSUM62' (for proteins) or the file 'EDNAFULL' (for nucleic sequences). These files are found in the 'data' directory of the EMBOSS installation.

The gap open penalty is the score taken away when a gap is created. The best value depends on the choice of comparison matrix. The default value assumes you are using the EBLOSUM62 matrix for protein sequences, and the EDNAFULL matrix for nucleotide sequences.

The gap extension, penalty is added to the standard gap penalty for each base or residue in the gap. This is how long gaps are penalized. Usually you will expect a few long gaps rather than many short gaps, so the gap extension penalty should be lower than the gap penalty. An exception is where one or both sequences are single reads with possible sequencing errors in which case you would expect many single base gaps. You can get this result by setting the gap open penalty to zero (or very low) and using the gap extension penalty to control gap scoring.

The end gap open penalty is the score taken away when an end gap is created. The best value depends on the choice of comparison matrix. The default value assumes you are using the EBLOSUM62 matrix for protein sequences, and the EDNAFULL matrix for nucleotide sequences.
The end gap extension, penalty is added to the end gap penalty for each base or residue in the end gap. This is how long end gaps are penalized.

parameter.name: e_gapopen
parameter.prompt: Gap opening penalty (Floating point number from 1.0 to 100.0)

message.text: Value greater than or equal to 0.0 is required
Value less than or equal to 100.0 is required

comment.text: The gap open penalty is the score taken away when a gap is created. The best value depends on the choice of comparison matrix. The default value assumes you are using the EBLOSUM62 matrix for protein sequences, and the EDNAFULL matrix for nucleotide sequences.

comment.text: The gap extension, penalty is added to the standard gap penalty for each base or residue in the gap. This is how long gaps are penalized. Usually you will expect a few long gaps rather than many short gaps, so the gap extension penalty should be lower than the gap penalty. An exception is where one or both sequences are single reads with possible sequencing errors in which case you would expect many single base gaps. You can get this result by setting the gap open penalty to zero (or very low) and using the gap extension penalty to control gap scoring.
